awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GEM--Comparing Simulations of Electron Acceleration in Kinetic Alfven Waves with Observations from the Van Allen Probes in the Inner Magnetosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The focus of this project is study a class of waves known as kinetic Alfven waves (KAWs) that may play an important role in the formation of the aurora. New observations from the Van Allen Probes mission show that these waves are a common during space weather storms. Interactions between these KAWs and electrons can result in penetration of these electrons into the atmosphere. Their penetration into the upper atmosphere leads to changes into electrical characteristics of the upper atmosphere. Understanding the factors that control the electrical properties of the upper atmosphere is essential to producing better space weather forecasts. The project will use a combination of numerical models and observations to investigate the process that transfers energy from the KAWs to the electrons. Undergraduate and graduate students will actively participate in this project. The investigators will also plan to provide opportunities for undergraduates to participate in the research through partnership with National Undergraduate Fellowship Program in Plasma Physics and Fusion Energy Sciences program. 

The proposers will use a hybrid Gyrofluid-Kinetic-Electron (GKE) model to study the recently observed traveling and standing Alfven waves prevalent through the inner magnetosphere during substorms. Van Allen probes data will be used to derive simulation parameters and compare with simulation output. This investigation will determine how and to what extent KAW energy flux is converted to electron energy flux in the inner magnetosphere. It will determine to what extent this mechanism is an efficient and effective pathway for enhanced energization and scattering of plasmasheet electrons into the loss cone, for additional heating of the ionosphere due to this scattering and for additional Poynting flux into the ionosphere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recent observations of the Van Allen probes spacecraft (many performed by our collaborators at the University of California Berkeley) have established the ubiquitous nature of both standing and traveling kinetic Alfven waves in the inner magnetosphere that are seen to peak during injections associated with sub-storm onset. While the observational analysis has clearly established the Alfvenic nature of these waves and the important role they play in facilitating soft electron precipitation and ionospheric ion outflow, for a detailed understanding of the wave-particle interactions, supplementing the observational results with simulation data is important. To this end, this collaborative study was designed to complement the observational analysis of spacecraft data (led by UC Berkeley) with simulation/theoretical studies that were led by the University of Alaska Fairbanks in collaboration with Andrews University. The simulations were carried out using a simulation model that treats the ion physics with a gyrofluid representation that includes the physics of the ion polarization current and ion gyroradius effects (important for capturing the characteristics of the kinetic Alfven wave propagation) self-consistently coupled to a kinetic electron description needed to study the particle energization. This report summarizes the computational/theoretical efforts with reference to the observational work of our UCB collaborators to support the conclusions drawn. We leave a detailed account of the observational results to their report.

The modeling effort was divided into independent considerations of standing and traveling kinetic Alfven modes, where in both cases we have undertaken studies that tailored the simulations to spacecraft observations. In one study, regarding standing modes, we took advantage of Van Allen Probes (VAP) and Cluster spacecraft observations that were at similar geomagnetic locations, but different altitudes to study the electron response along the field line. The study revealed very good agreement between a couple of features of the observed electron distribution functions, namely the highly asymmetric (enhanced along the magnetic field direction) features which the simulations revealed to be linked to trapping of electrons in the standing wave potential field and loss cone features illustrating precipitation of electrons directly by the wave.  These latter simulation results offer direct evidence of  wave driven electron precipitation that has been inferred from the statistical correlations between Alfvenic fluctuations and field-aligned electron fluxes derived  from our collaborator's observational analysis. More recent analysis of these simulations have begun to quantify the large extent of the wave energy sink associated with this energization.

Regarding traveling Alfven waves, we also took advantage of Van Allen probes observations to set up the background parameters of the simulations, but then conducted a series of simulations varying the cold electron fraction to ascertain how this affected the quantitative comparison with these observations. It was revealed that, firstly, the inclusion of a cold electron population significantly improved the quantitative nature of the observational comparison suggesting that cold electrons are always present along field lines. Secondly, the simulations revealed how sensitive the characteristics of the asymmetric distributions was to the exact cold electron fraction.

While the aforementioned simulation results helped directly explain features that were evident in the observations, they also revealed details that are not readily apparent. For example, the simulation results for the traveling Alfven waves revealed that highly asymmetric electron distributions exist in both upward and downward current regions (not easily discernable from observations because of  the VAP particle detector temporal cadence), but that only the occurrence in one current region was attributed to electron trapping.  In the simulation downward current region, the large asymmetry appeared after the wave had propagated past the observation point rather than at the peak of the wave current. Analysis of simulation electron trajectories revealed that in the latter case, predominantly cold electrons were not being trapped (because of the change in sign of the wave potential), but preferentially bulk energized by the KAW potential and accelerated in the direction in opposition to the wave motion (which helps carry the parallel current).

In summary, the simulation work done under this project has elucidated physical explanations for the observed field aligned-electron distributions that are ubiquitous in the inner magnetosphere; has clearly established the ability of these waves to facilitate soft electron precipitation that is important for magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling and has illustrated that this energization can be a significant sink of Alfven wave energy in the inner magnetosphere. As discussed by our UCB collaborators, these findings have implications beyond the explanations of these observations as for example, the precipitation of these electrons into the upper atmosphere stimulates the flow of ions outward into the magnetosphere (verified in a related study). Additionally, the insights developed for this research can contribute to our understanding of electron energization by kinetic scale Alfven waves in the Jupiter magnetosphere as recent Juno satellite observations have illustrated the ubiquitous nature of Alfvenic energization in this giant planet magnetosphere.
